I dont think the question "do tax cuts stimulate the economy" is quite fair. Of course they do. The real question is: are they the most efficient way to stimulate the economy? There the answer is a resounding no.
 
 1) Tax cuts overwhelmingly benefit the rich. This is because in our progressive system, the rich pay more taxes. Hence, they get more back in return when we cut them. The poor get less money back because they pay less (this is the argument conservatives use to respond to allegations that the cut is slanted towards the rich). Regardless of whether this can be helped or not (I think it can, by cutting payroll taxes and expanding the EITC), the fact remains the stimulus directed towards the wealthy is a relatively inefficient method of stimumlus. The law of diminishing returns (AKA the Utility Theory) states that as money is moved from poorer people to richer people, it is "worth" less. Poor people are more likely to spend, and more likely to spend here (so they have a higher multiplier effect). Rich folks are more likely to save or spend on imported luxury goods, which helps Switzerland, but not us.
 2) Even if you buy the Bush propoganda that the latest 350 bil. tax cut will create 1.4 million jobs (all evidence aside), that's spending a whopping $250,000/job created. That's a terrible yield, at that rate we should just pay folks a tripple the median income and we still create more jobs at a lower cost. The CBA doesn't work here.
 3) Rubinomics vs. "Voodoo" economics: Rubinomics (named for Clinton Treasury Sec. Robert Rubin) do not disdain tax cuts entirely. Rather they concoct a mix of middle/lower income tax cuts with paying down the debt. Debt/deficits are a huge drag on the economy, and according to the CBO, they will reach a cumulitive 4 trillion over the next 10 years (assuming the tax cuts are made permanent). The Brookings Inst. explains why, pointing out that dollars the government has to borrow are dollars unavailable to the public, thus pushing up interest rates and slowing down growth. By balancing the budget (which includes not spending on irresponsible programs/tax cuts) we provide insurance not just for the economic future, but the social future as well.

 Tue Nov 25,10:05 AM ET Add Business - Reuters to My Yahoo! 
 
 NEW YORK (Reuters) - U.S. consumer confidence (news - web sites) surged to its highest level in over a year, exceeding economists' rosy expectations, as consumers grew more hopeful about the job market, a report said on Tuesday. 
 
 Private research firm the Conference Board (news - web sites) said its index of consumer confidence climbed to 91.7, its highest level since Sept. 2002, from a revised 81.7 in October. Wall Street analysts had forecast a rise to 85.0. 
 
 "Consumers believe a slow but sure labor market turnaround is underway," said Lynn Franco, director of research at the Conference Board. 
 
 The percentage of consumers saying that jobs were hard to get fell to 29.5 percent in November from 33.7 percent the previous month. Consumers' view of the future grew rosier, lifting the expectations component of the index to 99.4 in Nov. from 91.5. The present situation index rose to 80.1 from 67.0. "
